raw_text:
Berlin cheers for anti-Nazi film
 
 A German movie about an anti-Nazi resistance heroine has drawn loud applause at Berlin Film Festival.
 
 Sophie Scholl - The Final Days portrays the final days of the member of the White Rose movement. Scholl, 21, was arrested and beheaded with her brother, Hans, in 1943 for distributing leaflets condemning the "abhorrent tyranny" of Adolf Hitler. Director Marc Rothemund said: "I have a feeling of responsibility to keep the legacy of the Scholls going." "We must somehow keep their ideas alive," he added.
 
 The film drew on transcripts of Gestapo interrogations and Scholl's trial preserved in the archive of communist East Germany's secret police. Their discovery was the inspiration behind the film for Rothemund, who worked closely with surviving relatives, including one of Scholl's sisters, to ensure historical accuracy on the film. Scholl and other members of the White Rose resistance group first started distributing anti-Nazi leaflets in the summer of 1942. They were arrested as they dropped leaflets at Munich University calling for a "day of reckoning" with Adolf Hitler's regime. The film focuses on the six days from Scholl's arrest to the intense trial which saw Scholl initially deny the charges and ended with a defiant appearance. It is one of three German films vying for a top prize at the Festival.
 
 A South African film version of Bizet's tragic opera Carmen shot in Cape Town in the Xhosa language has also premiered at the Berlin Festival. The film is entitled U-Carmen eKhayelitsha or Carmen in Khayelitsha after the township in which the story is set. It is performed by a 40-strong music and theatre troupe in their debut film performance. The film is the first South African feature in 25 years and only the second to be nominated for a Golden Bear Award.

The film uses transcripts of Gestapo interrogations and includes historical accuracy from surviving relatives.
It follows the six days leading up to Scholl's arrest and trial.
A South African film version of Carmen premiered at the festival in Cape Town.

A South African film version of Bizet's Carmen also premiered, performed by a 40-strong music and theatre troupe in their debut film performance.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: Berlin Film Festival erupted in loud applause for "Sophie Scholl - The Final Days," a film about the tragic resistance heroine Sophie Scholl, who was 21 when she was arrested along with her brother Hans in 1943.
Marc Rothemund expressed a sense of responsibility to preserve their legacy.
The film draws on transcripts from Gestapo interrogations and preserved trials in communist East Germany's archive.
It features surviving relatives, including Sophie Scholl's sister, to maintain historical accuracy.

The film focuses on six days: Scholl's arrest in 1942, her release at Munich University calling for a "day of reckoning," the intense trial leading to her defiance, and its impact among Berlin filmmakers, winning a top prize.
A South African film version of Bizet's opera Carmen premiered, titled U-Carmen eKhayilitsha or Carmen in Khayelitsha, featuring a 40-strong troupe for its debut performance.
It's the first South African feature in five years and the second to win the Golden Bear Award.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Berlin Film Festival has awarded a prize for "Sophie Scholl - The Final Days," a German movie based on an anti-Nazi resistance heroine who portrays her final days in captivity after being arrested and accused of distributing anti-German leaflets.

The film draws on transcripts of Gestapo interrogations as well as surviving members of the White Rose resistance group, who were arrested during the summer of 1942 and tried for conspiracy to commit terrorism.
The film premiered at Berlin's German Film Festival in August alongside a South African production shot in Xhosa language.
The film is the first South African feature in 25 years and only the second to be nominated for a Golden Bear Award.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The Berlin Film Festival has declared Sophie Scholl - The Final Days a winner in its competition for the prestigious Silver Bear Prize.
The movie, directed by Marc Rothemund, captures the final days of the White Rose movement activist who was executed alongside her brother Hans for distributing anti-Nazi leaflets in Germany in 1943.
The film draws on transcripts from the Gestapo's interrogations and the testimony of Scholl's sisters to ensure historical accuracy.
Scholl and other members of the White Rose resistance group first started distributing anti-Nazi leaflets in the summer of 1942, leading to their arrest and execution.
The film features a diverse array of actors, including Rita Orazi, who portrays Sophie in German.

The film is based on transcripts from Gestapo interrogations and Scholl's trial that were preserved in East Germany's secret police archive.
It premiered at the Berlin Festival as one of three German films vying for a top prize.
Another South African film about Bizet's Carmen, titled U-Carmen eKhayelitsha or Carmen in Khayelitsha, was also presented at the festival.

granite3.1-dense:2b: At Berlin Film Festival, Sophie Scholl - The Final Days, a German film directed by Marc Rothemund, received standing ovations.

The movie depicts the final days of Sophie Scholl, a 21-year-old member of the White Rose resistance movement who was arrested and beheaded with her brother in 1943 for distributing anti-Nazi leaflets.
Rothemund prioritized historical accuracy by collaborating with surviving relatives and utilizing Gestapo interrogation transcripts from East Germany's secret police archive.
The film focuses on the six days between Scholl's arrest and her trial, emphasizing her initial denial of charges before a defiant appearance.
In other Berlin Festival news, U-Carmen eKhayelitsha, a South African film adaptation of Bizet's Carmen in Xhosa, premiered.
Performed by a 40-member troupe, this is the first South African feature in 25 years and only the second nominated for a Golden Bear Award.
The film, set in the township of Khayelitsha, marks the debut cinematic work of this talented ensemble.
chatgpt-4o-latest: A German film, *Sophie Scholl - The Final Days*, received strong applause at the Berlin Film Festival for its portrayal of anti-Nazi resistance heroine Sophie Scholl.
The movie focuses on the last six days of Scholl’s life, from her arrest to her trial and execution in 1943 for distributing anti-Nazi leaflets.
Director Marc Rothemund used Gestapo interrogation transcripts and worked with Scholl’s relatives to ensure historical accuracy.
The film is one of three German entries competing for a top prize.
Also premiering at the festival was *U-Carmen eKhayelitsha*, a South African adaptation of *Carmen* in the Xhosa language, performed by a local theatre troupe.
It is the first South African feature in 25 years and only the second to be nominated for a Golden Bear Award.
